author: Rae Paoletta
title: Why 466-Million-Year-Old Meteorites Are Still Raining Down on Earth
text:
Go to permalink Image credit: NASA/JPL 
When the solar system was in its rebellious stage about 466 million years ago, two massive asteroids collided in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, sending tiny pieces of shrapnel flying all over the solar system. After examining bits of crystals that fell to Earth just before the collision, an international team of scientists has learned that space rocks that only enter our atmosphere rarely now were much more prevalent back in the day. And stuff from that big breakup is still raining down on us. Advertisement 
In other words, a single collision before the time of the dinosaurs appears to have influenced the types of space rocks bombarding the Earth for hundreds of millions of years. To demonstrate that, the group analyzed the composition ancient micrometeorites—tiny shards of space rock—from just before the big smashup 466 million years ago, that were retrieved from an ancient seafloor in a Russian river valley. The team’s findings have been published in Nature Astronomy. 
“What this study did was it went a little before that major breakup event took place,” William Botke, a contributor to the paper, told Gizmodo. “It said, ‘What are the meteorites falling on the ground [almost 500 million years ago] like?’ And what they found is that the total fractions of the different kinds of meteorites back then are very different than what we’re getting today.” NASA/Fred Bruenjes 
After dissolving the micrometeorites in acid, the team was left with tiny microscopic chromite crystals. The group found that 34 percent of the pre-collision meteorites they studied were primitive achondrites , which make up only 0.45 percent of meteorites found on Earth today. Primitive achondrites come from asteroids that were heated to the point where they were melted. Today, the mix of meteorites is very different, likely reflecting the fallout of the big collision, the researchers say. Advertisement 
On one hand, it’s awe-inspiring for scientists and space geeks alike that we’re still seeing the effects of an event that took place almost 500 million years ago. 
“There’s a long tail,” Buttke said. “Think of it like a landslide. The landslide starts with this initial flux, which is really heavy. But the landslide takes a little while to die down. So even towards the end, you’re still getting some stuff at the bottom of the tail.” 
But besides simply being interesting , as the study’s lead author, Dr. Phillip Heck called it, this research could give scientists an inside look into the history of asteroid collisions, and how the meteorites born as a result could have impacted life on Earth.   
“What we’re trying to do is go back and tell a story about when these break ups took place,” Bottke said. “Ultimately, we want to try and tie these all together. So for example, imagine some big asteroid broke up. We want to know if that asteroid delivered anything to Earth, and did it impact life?” 
For non-scientists, one solid takeaway is we get to see some of the same meteorites dinosaurs did. That’s objectively awesome. Advertisement
